I think it's important to note that New Orleans has become vulnerable to storms largely to benefit the rest of the United States.
Now that sediment goes off the continental shelf to keep the Mississippi River open, which benefits exports from, you know, the entire middle part of the country.
If you close down the Port of New Orleans, you're going to have a significant negative impact on the rest of the country.

You also have well over $100 billion in infrastructure that you're going to have to rebuild somewhere else, which, you know, again, the investment in Category 5 levees is cheap compared to rebuilding the infrastructure.

I think one point that's important to make here that has been somewhat lost is that the storm that flooded Katrina was a great storm as it hit the Gulf Coast, but New Orleans, the bulk of the city, the overwhelming majority of the city, was flooded from behind, not from the Gulf.
It was flooded from the north, from Lake Pontchartrain.
And the levees that were designed--the storm was not a great storm on the lake.
The Corps of Engineers has three standards for the storm they were designed to contain and Katrina fell short of each one of those three standards on the lake.
The levees simply failed.
